modal.title: Bombparty clone
modal.description:
Real-time web game using websockets, node.js and react.
Check out the website or github

What is this?

Inspired by BombParty on JKLM. From a simple request from my partner to make the game show the bomb timer came an incredibly fun journey into learning websockets.

The journey

From a simple timer counting down to a full fledged game that has sound effects, bombs, confetti, and awesome avatars. Features and stability credits go to my colleagues at Fuze who helped play test and came up with multiple ideas that helped make the game more interesting.

The architecture

The game was created using node.js, express and socket.io; It features real time private rooms, chat, confetti, a scoreboard, hardmode, bonus heart/letter rewards, random name and avatar generators. The dictionaries used are sowpods, enable1 and custom additions such as countries, months and days of the week. There's also a hidden feature that allows you to become an "admin" where you can kick other players (clicking on the ðŸ¤¯).

Give the game a try! I hope you enjoy it as much as I enjoyed building it.

timeline.description: An illustrated cat collection for cat lovers (2019)

modal.title: Cute Cat Avatars
modal.description:
An illustrated cat collection for cat lovers.
Check out the website or github

What is this?

Cute Cat Avatars are colorful cats illustrated by me that can be used as profile picture placeholders for live websites or design mock ups. Made in SVG format for a crisp image with super fast load times on every device.

How to use

You can easily use these cats in img tags or http requests, the response will be a cat in Content-Type: image/svg+xml. The url to request is https://cute-cat-avatars.fly.dev/api/v1/:seed for example:

HTML
<img src='https://cute-cat-avatars.fly.dev/api/v1/announcer' alt='Cute announcer cat'>
JavaScript
fetch('https://cute-cat-avatars.fly.dev/api/v1/cat').then(function(response) {document.getElementById('cat').src = response.url;})

modal.title: Ayotree
modal.description:
Ayotree's cloud-based school management software helps traditional and online schools manage scheduling, attendance, payments and virtual classrooms.

Role: Lead Front-end Developer

Check out the website

User flow

A userflow wireframe was created to illustrate the flow of pages, their content and how they link together.

Branding

The branding portrays an educational system that is caring and welcoming but clean and easy to understand.

Final Design

The Ayotree consumer facing website was designed to showcase it's online software suite that combines all the tools needed to run a successful online school.

modal.title: Portable Stool
modal.description:
The concept behind my stool is the ability for it to transform from its collapsed state into a seat through the use of a single swivel. Hence why the name "Swivel" was used as the name of the stool.

This is a school project with the objective of creating a portable seat.

Development

I began my process by sketching many ideas and concepts of what a portable stool would like it. I went through many ideas, but I found myself moving forward with something swivel like due to it's clever minimalistic design and feasibility of making it in time in the shops.

Prototyping

I built super small scale models to check if the aesthetic was something I liked visually. After approving of the visual I began building a full size model to learn more about the interaction between the pieces.

From the full scale prototype and user testing I identified 4 main problems I needed to solve to make my stool usable and user friendly.

Final Design

I made sure to fix the aforementioned problems and incorporate them into my final working model. My changes included: Changing the square seat into a triangle to prevent catching users thighs, adding a stopping block to the leg to stop the swiveling leg, attaching a magnet to the bottom of the seat that secures to the stopping block, adding leg pegs to increase stability, and finally adding a cushion for extra comfort.

modal.title: Task Lamp
modal.description:
This is a school project with the objective of creating a lighting fixture utilizing reflection.

Inspiration

My concept for this lamp was inspired by the organic curvatures of flowers. Mainly influenced by the magnolia flower and itâ€™s spiral like arrangement of petals. Images from www.wikimedia.org

Development

Starting with ideation I had tried to incorporate biomimicry into this project by taking the organic shapes of plants and turning it into a lamp. I created sketches to help me figure out areas such as the amount of lights, amount of pedals, what shape the pedals could be, where the transformer would go, how would the light reflect, how wide and tall would it be, where the cord would go, etc.

Prototyping

Prototyping helped me learn about the reflective properties of light and how it created an ambiance to it's environment. By making quick prototypes with LED lights I figured out how I wanted the final form of the lamp.

Final Design

The final outcome of the lamp came out as an elegantly sculptured desk lamp that was influenced by flowers; Designed to be organic, clean, and minimal.

Technical Drawings

modal.title: Branding Identity
modal.description:
This is a school project with the objective of creating a brand for the teenager headphone market.

Research

Before developing the brand I had to research about brands in the market as well as information about my target market. According to a survey about the top 10 coolest brands among more than 1,100 teens aged between 13 and 17. The most "cool" brand was YouTube. Then came Netflix, Google, Xbox, Oreos, GoPro, PlayStation, Doritos, and Nike, Chrome. These brands important to learn from not only because they are the most popular in their industry but because their brand image resonates the strongest with their customers.

Branding

I wanted to develop a brand that popped out to teenagers while remaining clean and easy to understand as well. I chose a bear as the logo to represent bold and adventurous, and headphones to portray that this is a music brand.

modal.title: Modular cooking platform
modal.description:
The design brief for this school project is to develop a flexible and adaptable cooking platform for shared kitchen environments such as households, dormitories and small offices. With the main feature of supporting multiple user food preparation scenarios.

Research

In our current system of production and consumption, products are designed, manufactured and consumed within a short period of time. These disposed products end up in landfills and is having a major negative effect on the environment as over 71,000 tonnes of e-waste has been tossed in 2012. [1]

Development

My idea was to design a cooking platform that is first and foremost portable and lightweight, and then focus on ways to make the it more personal to the user. During the concept development, I looked into different attachment methods, placement on the main body, the interface, the use cycle and material aesthetics. I explored ideas through sketching and low fidelity mock-ups.

User Testing

My goal for user testing was to test my ideas and low fidelity prototypes on users to have a greater understanding of potential problems with my designs and areas of improvement. For my testing, I had three main investigation questions:

Final Design

After several interface discussions with users I decided to incorporate the entire control interface on the large control knob. This makes it so that the base of the product can be as portable as possible, while also ensuring that the interface has only essential elements for users to understand what settings it is currently on.

modal.title: Faucet
modal.description:
This school project tasked me to design a faucet that reflects the Jaguar brand identity, while also remaining suitable to the look of a faucet and associated use, maintenance, safety and manufacturing considerations.

Team

The team consisted of myself, Omar Fakhuri, and Wasseem Al-Idrissi.

Research

Jaguar is one of the worldâ€™s fastest growing premium car manufacturers worldwide. They focus on producing high-quality luxury vehicles that appeal to customers globally. They are a British multinational car manufacturer that focuses on stimulating emotions and feelings to their customers. Our research found that the target audience of Jaguar consists mainly of wealthy middle aged professionals and executives, but they are attempting to attract potential millennial luxury customers. Images from www.jaguar.com

Development

We started laying out all of the research we could find about Jaguar on large brown paper and organizing them into specific sections. The sections we focused on were the marketing, personality, lifestyle and details/form. After we then began sketching and prototyping ideas and concepts to find a form that suited the brand and the research that we found.

Final Design

Our final design focused on the translating the form of their cars into the form of a faucet. Incorporating their signature gear knob as the faucet control and creating a form that relates to Jaguar's branding image.

modal.title: Organizer
modal.description:
Do you read at night? Is your bedside table full? Well forget about the hassle of getting up and putting your book away on the shelf because now there is a an organizer specifically for that. For this school project I designed a bedside organizer for books and utilities.

Research

To start off this project I decided to create a quick online survey to see how many users would be interested in a portable bedside table, as well as to find out about their book reading and storing habits. I posted this survey through social media and quickly got 41 participants. I was surprised to see that many participants would be interested in a portable bedside table even though almost everyone already has one. This helped give me an incentive to design a solution for this. I further inquired about how many, what kind, and what size the books that users had. This data helped guide my design decisions to make a product users would need.

Development

My idea was to create a portable table that is first and foremost small and lightweight. I focused on making it easy for users to use. During the concept development I utilized the results from my survey to guide many of my design decisions. Along with that I looked into different bed attachment methods, placement of the table platform, the number of book holders, and materials. I explored ideas through sketching and low fidelity mock-ups.

Final Design

My final design is a portable bedside table for books that is small enough to be taken anywhere. It is also designed to work with every existing bed out there. This versatile table was created to hold books or accessories where there is no table or table space available.

modal.title: End User Satisfaction Program
modal.description:
Service optimization is nearly impossible to perform without an honest and thorough understanding of end user sentiment toward IT services and software. - Info-Tech Research Group

Problem

During my time at Info-tech Research Group I was tasked to develop a survey which evaluated end user perspectives on company innovation, IT agility, and satisfaction with how technology enables them to do their job. Identify opportunities to improve the reputation of IT, both across the organization and within specific departments.

Team

The team consisted of myself as the designer and front-end developer, Chris O'Conner as the information researcher, and Taylor Phillips as the backend developer.

Product Goal

Share end user satisfaction and importance ratings of core IT services, IT communications and business enablement to focus on the right end user groups or lines of business, and ramp up satisfaction and productivity.

Research

Having the initial survey questions from Chris and the type of data that needed to be presented in the survey, I started off with many sketches to get ideas and concepts out of my head.

Wireframes & User Flow

After laying out the pages on wireframes we noticed that the it was difficult for the user to know where to start reading. After multiple designs and iterations I came with the solution to guide the user with arrows throughout the sections.

Final Design

After finalizing the user flow and making some final decisions with the team, I began on the high-fidelity designs. We had many different mockups and iterations. Everything was placed intentionality with good reasoning and decision making behind it. There were a lot of tradeoffs due to the amount of space that could be placed on a page, but that restriction also helped us condense the information so it was straight to the point.

modal.title: Metro Mobile App
modal.description:
This is an individual school project to design a Mobile App for a grocery store. This project involves app analysis, user flow, wireframes, visual mockups, and usage prototypes.

Benefits of having a Mobile App

Mobile apps give the benefits of providing customers with instant value such as convenience to coupons and flyers, as well as recieving instant news about promotions. At the time Metro did not have an app, thus I decided to focus on them for this project.

Flow Charts

I listed out the different tasks and subtasks in the app and mapped them based on their hierarchy to help me determine the overall structure and the links within different sections of the app.

Branding

This is a Metro branded app so the colours and look and feel need to match up with the company brand.

High fidelity design

modal.title: ROM
modal.description:
ROM is a concept app that is held inside the ROM museum for individuals to interact with and gain a deeper connection with the content displayed.

This is an individual school project that involves app analysis, user flow, wireframes, visual mockups, and usage prototypes.

Problem

Children and students touring museums can get quite bored of just simply viewing museum pieces. Providing a tool that allows them to interact with the content will allow them to gain higher satisfaction and a more memorable experience throughout the museum.

Wireframing concepts

I sketched and mocked up basic wireframe concepts to figure out elements such as navigation and layout. I wanted a simple, visual representation of the information so that it was easy to understand. From letting other students run through the wireframes I noticed that the flow was not as intuitive as I originally thought. This feedback helped tremendously to ensure I fixed the issues and continue in the right direction.

Final design

ROM bridges the gap between students and content so that they can interact with history, gain a deeper understanding to the pieces, and improve the overall experience of the museum.
